column1: Allocating Interventions Based on Predicted Outcomes: A Case Study on Homelessness Services
Amanda Kube@Washington University in St. Louis
column2: Sanmay Das@Washington University in St. Louis
column3: Patrick J. Fowler@Washington University in St. Louis

column1: AAAI Technical Track: AI for Social Impact

Modern statistical and machine learning methods are increasingly capable of modeling individual or personalized treatment effects. These predictions could be used to allocate different interventions across populations based on individual characteristics. In many domains
column3: the availability of different possible interventions can be severely resource limited. This paper considers possible improvements to the allocation of such services in the context of homelessness service provision in a major metropolitan area. Using data from the homeless system
column4: we use a counterfactual approach to show potential for substantial benefits in terms of reducing the number of families who experience repeat episodes of homelessness by choosing optimal allocations (based on predicted outcomes) to a fixed number of beds in different types of homelessness service facilities. Such changes in the allocation mechanism would not be without tradeoffs
column5: however; a significant fraction of households are predicted to have a higher probability of re-entry in the optimal allocation than in the original one. We discuss the efficiency
column6: equity and fairness issues that arise and consider potential implications for policy.
